chapter.title: What's Covered?
chapter.para: Get started with &susemgr; 3 by setting up a KVM learning environment. This quick-start guide will provide you with introductory guidance on setting up a &susemgr; server. You will learn the basics of managing both traditional &susemgr; clients and Salt clients. This guide is intended for system administrators.

sect1.title: Introducing &susemgr;
sect1.para: &susemgr; lets you efficiently manage large sets of Linux systems and keep them up to date. It provides automated and cost-effective software management, asset management, and system provisioning. &susemgr; provides a best in class solution for organizations requiring absolute control of maintenance and package deployment on their servers. It allows customers the highest level of flexibility and power ensuring their servers remain secure while facilitating and advancing an organizations system life-cycle requirements.

formalpara.title: Salt
Salt-master
formalpara.para: &susemgr; &productnumber3; takes a commanding role as a Salt-master capable of orchestrating thousands of Salt-minions (&susemgr; Clients) via remote execution.

formalpara.title: Distribution Management
formalpara.para: &susemgr; &productnumber3; is also fully compatible with Red Hat Satellite Server and offers seamless management of both &sle; and &rhel; Linux client systems.

sect1.title: Overview
sect1.para: &susemgr; may be integrated within your network infrastructure in multiple ways. In this guide you will be installing &susemgr; 3 as an add-on to &sle; 12 SP1 utilizing either the JeOS (Just Enough Operating System) image or alternatively the full SLES12 SP1 DVD Image within a KVM virtual machine. You will register your &susemgr; server with &scc; then sync or (Mirror) the &sle; 12 SP1 channel(Channels may also be referred to a mirrored repository, containing software updates and patch data.) for a client which will be registered with &susemgr;.

sect1.title: Prerequisites for Installation
sect1.para: This guide requires that you have created an account with &scc;(SCC). During installation of both &sle; 12 SP1 and &susemgr; &productnumber3;, &scc; credentials will be requested and you must enter them to receive the latest packages and updates. The following procedure will guide you through obtaining your &scc; Organizational Credentials.

step.para: Open a browser and direct it to:
If you have not done so, create an account now.
Log in to your new &scc; account.
Under the Management tools widget select Manage Users.
Click on the Organization Credentials tab.
Keep this information handy during &susemgr; 3 setup.

note.title: Just Enough Operating System (JeOS, "Juice") vs. Full Media Image
note.para: The &sle; 12 SP1 JeOS image provides the quickest route for setup of a test environment. The JeOS image total size is about 240MB. The alternative would be the 3GB &sle; 12 SP1 installation ISO. Both installation media are appropriate, but depend upon available bandwidth or your application needs. Both methods of installation will be covered in this guide.

sect1.title: Additional Requirements
sect1.para: To successfully complete this guide there are some network requirements that must be met. The following section will walk you through these requirements.

formalpara.title: Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN):
formalpara.para: The &susemgr; server must resolve its FQDN correctly or cookies will not work properly on the WebUI. For more information on FQDN see:

formalpara.title: Hostname and IP Address:
formalpara.para: To ensure that &susemgr;'s domain name can be resolved by its clients, both server and client machines must be connected to a working Domain Name System (DNS) server. This guide assumes the required infrastructure exists within your environment. For more information on setting up a (DNS) server see:

important.title: Naming Your Server
important.para: The hostname of &susemgr; must not contain uppercase letters as this may cause jabberd to fail. Choose the hostname of your &susemgr; server carefully. Although changing the server name is possible, it is a complex process and unsupported.
